Short title and commencement.[Bui 9]A [13 Geo. 5.]Merchandise Marks.1ABILLto- -Amend the Merchandise Marks Acts, 1887 to a.d. 1923. 1911, in respect of imported agricultural produce.IlE it enacted by the King's most Excellent Majesty, ) by and with the advice and consent of the Lords Spiritual and Temporal, and Commons, in this present Parliament assembled, and by the authority of the same, 5 as follows: 1. Section sixteen of the Merchandise Marks Act, Importation 1887 (which relates to prohibition of importation) shall of certain apply to the following agricultural produce as if the agripultural same were thereby prohibited to be imported into Great pro uce' 10 Britain, that is to say :-(a) Imported meat unless it is indelibly marked in such manner as maybe prescribed by regula-tions made by the Minister of Agriculture and fisheries and the Board of Agriculture for15 Scotland (in this Act referred to as " the De-partments") acting jointly, so as to indicate clearly either the country in which the meat was produced or that the meat is imported produce. Provided that in the case of pieces20 of meat which are customarily imported in abox, barrel or like package, the regulations may permit the importation thereof if the meat is imported in a box, barrel or package on which there is conspicuously branded or25 stamped the name of the country in whichthe meat was produced or the words " imported meat" ;[Bill 9] A 2 2Merchandise Maries.[13 Geo. 5.](6) Imported eggs unless each egg is indelibly marked with a clear indication of the country in which the eggs were produced or with the word "imported";(c) Imported raw fruit or vegetables or fruit pulp 5unless such produce either is contained in a package on which there is conspicuously branded or stamped the name of the country in which the same was produced or the word "imported," or, in the case of any article which may be 1J exempted from such requirement by a regulation made by the Departments acting jointly, is contained in a package to which is attached a label bearing such name or word; or(d) Poultry or dairy produce unless each box, tin or 15 other package in which the produce is contained is conspicuously branded or stamped with the name of the country in which the article was produced or the word " imported."2.-(1) Any person who shall, except as otherwise 2( provided by this section, expose for sale by retail any imported meat unless it bears at the time of exposure for sale a label with the word " imported," or with a word or words indicating the country of origin of the meat clearly printed thereon, so as to be easily readable by a 25 purchaser shall be guilty of an offence against this Act.. (2) Where only imported meat is exposed for sale on any slab, rail or counter, it shall be a sufficient compliance with the requirements of this section if the slab, rail or counter bears such a label in a conspicuous 3( position so as to be easily readable by a purchaser.(3) Where all the meat for the time being on sale on any premises is imported meat, it shall be a sufficient compliance with the requirements of this section if there is exhibited on the premises in a conspicuous position, 35 and so as to be easily readable by a purchaser, a notice stating that imported meat only is on sale.(4); Where pieces of imported meat and other meat, not exceeding in any case 1 lb. in weight, are exposed for sale on a slab, tray or counter, the provisions of sub- I section (1) of this section shall not apply to the imported meat so exposed if the slab, tray or counter, bears in a conspicuous position a notice containing the words [13 Geo. 5.] Merchandise Marks. 3;" .' ' ;V :. - , ' ," mixed imported meat and other meat" clearly printed A.D. 1923.thereon.(5) Where any imported meat sold to a pnrchaser is delivered to him at any place other than premises on which meat is sold.or exposed for sale by the seller, the meat shall be accompanied by an invoice or ticket indicating clearly that the meat is imported, and any seller of imported meat who fails to comply with this provision shall be guilty of an offence against this Act.JflO 3. Any person who shall remove, efface or obliterate Removal or from any imported produce to which this Act applies or obliteration from any package containing such produce any mark ofnmrks-placed thereon or label attached thereto in compliance IJ20 with the requirements of section, one of this Act shall be guilty of an offence against this Act, unless he shows to the satisfaction of the court that the removal, effacement or obliteration was not for the purpose of concealing the fact that the produce was imported.[25 5. An officer of a local authority empowered to Power of execute and enforce the provisions of this Act, may, if entry. [35 authorised in that behalf by the local authority and upon production, if so required, of such authority, enter any premises on which he has reason to believe that there is imported produce to which this Act applies and take samples of any article which appears to him to be such J40 imported produce, and any person who obstructs an officer so authorised in the execution of the powers 4Merchandise Marks.[13 Geo. 5.]A.D. 1923. conferred on him by this section shall be guilty of an ' offence against this Act.Legal pro- 7.-(1) Any offence against this Act maybe pro-oeedings and seeuted and any fine under this Act may be recovered, penalties. in England and Wales in manner directed by the Summary Jurisdiction Acts, and in Scotland in manner directed by the Summary Procedure Act, 1864, and any Acts amending the same.(2) Any person who is found guilty of an offence against this Act shall be liable to a fine not exceeding io twenty pounds, and in the case of a second or sub-sequent offence to imprisonment with or without hard labour for a term not exceeding six months or to a fine not exceeding fifty pounds.(3) A person shall not be liable to conviction for an 15 offence against this Act in respect of any imported article if he shows to the satisfaction of the Court that he did not know and could not-with reasonable diligence have ascertained that the article was imported.(4) This section shall not apply to an offence 20 relating to the importation of any article.Definitions. 8.--(l) In this Act the expression "meat" shall include beef, veal, mutton, lamb, pork, bacon and ham, but shall not include cooked, canned or potted meat or sausages or offals.(2) Any article produced in Northern Ireland and brought to Great Britain from a port in Northern Ireland shall not be deemed to be imported produce for the purposes of this Act.Short title 9.
